comments.commentBody: This is exactly what this Tea Party Conservative Republican voted for, and why the criticism of people like me by people like you that we're in the pocket of Big Business couldn't be further from the truth. Your glee is misplaced and very telling.

Could not happen to a nicer group of people.  The No Regulations types were sold a bill of goods by the Republicans and now they get to whine about it in the New York Times.  There are multiple layers of justice right here.

I highly doubt they are capable of starting over. Instead, they will use the SCOTUS decision to cudgel each other and gain political points.

Which do you think Obama is more concerned about right now: the impact on the uninsured if the ACA is struck down or on his own re-election?

I apologize, Howie. By the time I posted that late last night, I was in a foul mood for reasons that had nothing to do with this blog, was dead tired and had probably had a bit too much wine. I was, in short, spoiling for a fight and invented an offense through a circuitous route that involved a couple of different posts. No sense tracing that train of thought.

I regretted it almost as soon as I posted it, and I would note that this is not the first time I've apologized for something within the last 24 hours.

Rich, C'Mon, you know full well I'm a card and I wasn't the least bit serious, I was joshing, just as I thought you were, and like Leapy said, no hard feelings where none were intended...are you down with that, Rich...I sure hope so?
All the best good buddy
C U around the WP club

Howie
A "big majority of citizens" are grossly uninformed.

Because the mandate is unconstitutional and needs to be thrown out. However, Congress does have the power to REGULATE interstate commerce and can require the insurance industry, if they are going to be in the business of selling insurance, they must accept any and all participants. But without the increased pool of heallthy participants, the insurance for all clause will become financially unfeasible. Which is what the Supreme Court is trying to decide. Can Congress enact financially unfeasable laws that would put an undue burden on the provider?
Because it is much harder to get a constitutional ammendment passed than it is to pass a bill behind closed doors that no body even read or understood what was in it.

If someone doesn't have insurance and walks into a medical office or emergency room they get an invoice. There is no free ride just because you decided not to buy insurance.

If you can't afford to pay the invoice, after emptying you saving accounts and selling any other assets, you might have to declare bankruptcy or just work off the debt like Americans have for centuries.
Thank you, Peg - this is the most cogent, rational explanation of this issue I've read yet. I wish our Supreme Court justices could read it.

Scratching my head. Let's just forget young or old. It's the bus that hits you, the broken leg skiing, cancer, or let's just say the fall in the street while texting. How on earth can we live in a country where insurance is not required? We are insane.

follow the money, the rich don't want to pay for the poor ever again in any amount, but they also know this reflects on them in a very poor light so they obfuscate to no end and the uneducated end up voting/fighting against their own interests because they do not understand they are being emotionally manipulated.  it is the American way and yes i see how it would be difficult to understand when you apply reason and logic.  unfortunately this is how selfish our culture has become.  in short, we will reap what we sow.

Only the extremely poor qualify for Medicaid. A definite fine for failing to enroll in insurance is a much better motivation to enroll than what many people will see as a long shot that they will need hospital services or other critical medical care.

There are some people who think they're invulnerable & the rules don't apply to them. The same people who don't want to purchase health insurance tend to be those who think they can drink & drive, have unprotected sex with multiple random strangers & never get STDs or pregnant, or commit crimes without getting caught, etc. We call these people sociopaths. Or Republicans.
I got word from my doctor today that I need surgery. I need to have my mandate removed. Not sure if my insurance covers that, however.

Your illness may be hazardous to my health.  That's the problem.  If you have a contagious disease or any other ailment that might affect me adversely, I want you to get treatment now.  I do the same for you.  The fact that you don't feel like paying for health care, or health insurance, is not the point.  You have an obligation to others, if not to yourself, to be healthy.  Deal with it.

You do realize there are THREE branches of government. Congress creates the legislation. The President signs it into law and the Supreme Court rules on matters of constutionallity. The President can veto a bill and Congress can override that veto and the Supreme Court can rule whether or not it fits within the constitution. Obviously you are not an American citizen or been here very long or you would understand this. The Supreme Court is will within its powers to rule on the Constitutionallity of the ACA and whether or not provisions in the Act would place an undue burden on the insurance providers.
Thank you...you make my point even stronger, There is legal precedent that the commerce clause can be used in this case which is far more pressing and will effect the buying of health care.

When so many persons in this wonderful land are in trouble, for many reasons, it may do us good to say that we want everyone to look forward to monitoring their health more closely and live a better life. That means all of us and for the long run way into the future. It is not possible to get away from being selfish and restrictive? I grew up in a family of 10 where my father was out of work for 19 years as we grew up and we all helped each other and then helped others outside of the family because we knew that helping each other made us happy for life. Think about that.
The best pick for him would be Bonzo, or maybe Bozo.

Moreover, I'd like one of these folks to point out a state that requires that in purchasing car insurance, I have to subsidize someone else's car insurance. Or a state that requires that car insurance cover the cost of oil changes and other regular maintenance.

When I was a child, no one I knew had health insurance. Now, thanks to government involvement in healthcare, a trip to the doctor is something you need insurance for. Let me ask you, why does insurance seem so necessary and why is it so expensive? Does it have something to do with covering the equivalent of oil changes? In the mid nineties I lost my job and insurance, for which I was paying a share of about three hundred dollars a month. I signed up for an individual policy in Texas where I take it there were not a thousand government mandates legally required of every policy. With a deductible of about two thousand dollars and an agreement that I would not have a baby I got that policy for about fifty dollars a month.

I must say I was impressed by the originality of the theme. A piece of music embedded into a crossword? That was a real first.

Now I want to see a crossword that consists *entirely* of tunes. Make it so!

Taxpayers do not pick up the tab of those without insurance. It´s those people who can afford insurance who pick it up by paying higher premiums. As premiums mount, fewer can afford it. This is why the individual mandate is important. It´s end this upward spiral in the cost of health care.

Taxpayers pick up the tab of those without insurance. If we were to turn away those who need help, refuse them coverage at the unbelievably expensive emergency rooms, then what? Think about this. When someone, too poor to afford coverage, goes to the emergency rooms for coughs, fevers or whatever minor aliment, and then costing the taxpayers exorbitant charges from those hospitals, which system is best?
Are we that stupid to not see the correlation between service and charges? Protection of our poor? How about just having the best medical system available to all? Socialized medicine... a dirty word, but absolutely the only answer to this ridiculous situation.

Actually, $1400 is MORE than the MacBook Air (which costs $1300).

And yes, that's a nosebleed price on the Ultrabooks scale.

I disagree. Remember: you lose 1/2 of that 128 gigabytes right out of the box--to Windows, apps, and junkware!

64 gigs really truly is a tiny amount. "20 bazillion digital photos?" Plenty of people need 40-50 gigs JUST for their music, let alone photos and videos.

Apple's models are also ultra-expensive.

Nobody's disputing that. These are luxury laptops.

The comparison here is with other WINDOWS laptops, which can be had for $400 or even less. Compared with that, ultra books are indeed ultra-expensive.

(Your comment about Apple's pricing being "outrageous." Here are 7 companies making the same kind of laptop in the same price range! So are they all outrageous, too?)

Oh, how cynical.  What would you prefer they spend money on?  Health insurance?  No way.  That would be infringing on their autonomy.  Taxes to pay for infrastructure improvements, mass transit, education, renewable energy.  Come on, get a life.

Windows has more third party software written for its operating system and a lot of it is free. Apple lovers aren't allowed to criticize the product's lack of features. When I got my mac as a gift I went to a workshop at Apple to ask how to do a long list of things I could do with Windows. Almost all those options were not available on a mac. Why? Apple is so sure they know what's best they don't allow enough personalization of use. There are three different ways to do everything in Windows.
I plan to put Windows on its own partition. The question is how small can I make for the partition for the mac OS. Apple's website has instructions for putting Windows on a mac, but nobody would want the mac OS on their PC.
